title: 4 Ways to Reset a Hard Drive on PC or Mac

steps.title: Click the menu.
steps.content: Click the menu. It’s usually at the bottom-left corner of the screen. This method will delete all of the data on your hard drive and replace it with its original factory settings. Make sure to back up your data before you begin.

steps.title: Click Settings.
steps.content: Click Settings. It’s near the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Click Update & security.
steps.content: Click Update & security . [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Recovery.
steps.content: Click Recovery . It’s in the left column.

steps.title: Click Get started under “Reset this PC.”
steps.content: Click Get started under “Reset this PC.”

steps.title: Select Remove everything.
steps.content: Select Remove everything . This ensures that all of your apps and personal data will be deleted from the hard drive.

steps.title: Select a drive-cleaning option.
steps.content: Select a drive-cleaning option. If you’re resetting the PC because someone else will be using it, click Remove files and clean the drive to ensure that they won’t be able to access your data. If you plan to keep the PC, click Just remove my files . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . Another confirmation will appear.

steps.title: Click Reset.
steps.content: Click Reset . Windows will now begin the reset process. Once the process is complete, follow the prompts to set up Windows as new.

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+S.
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + S . This opens the Windows search bar. This method will help you delete the data from a hard drive on your computer that isn’t your primary drive.

steps.title: Type management.
steps.content: Type management .

steps.title: Click Computer Management.
steps.content: Click Computer Management .

steps.title: Select Disk Management under “Storage.”
steps.content: Select Disk Management under “Storage.” It’s in the left column. You may have to click the arrow next to “Storage” to see Disk Management. A list of hard drives connected to your PC will appear.

steps.title: Right-click the disk you want to reset.
steps.content: Right-click the disk you want to reset. You can select any drive other than the one on which Windows is installed.

steps.title: Click Format.
steps.content: Click Format .

steps.title: Click Yes.
steps.content: Click Yes . The data on the hard drive will be deleted.

steps.title: Make sure your Mac is connected to the internet.
steps.content: Make sure your Mac is connected to the internet. You’ll need a way to access your Mac’s factory settings once your hard drive is erased, so your computer must be online. [3] X Research source This method will delete all of the data on your hard drive and replace it with its original factory settings. Make sure to back up your data before you begin.

steps.title: Click the menu.
steps.content: Click the menu. It’s at the top-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Click Restart….
steps.content: Click Restart… . Your Mac will now shut down and restart. You’ll have to perform the next step before the login screen appears so act quickly.

steps.title: Press ⌘ Command+R on the slate gray screen.
steps.content: Press ⌘ Command + R on the slate gray screen. This screen appears after the computer shuts down and begins to restart. The Utilities panel will appear.

steps.title: Click Disk Utility.
steps.content: Click Disk Utility .

steps.title: Select your hard drive.
steps.content: Select your hard drive. The name varies by Mac but it will appear in the left panel. Look for a drive with a name like “startup disk.”

steps.title: Click the Erase tab.
steps.content: Click the Erase tab. It’s in the main panel.

steps.title: Click Format.
steps.content: Click Format .

steps.title: Select Mac OS Extended (Journaled).
steps.content: Select Mac OS Extended (Journaled) .

steps.title: Click Erase.
steps.content: Click Erase . The data on your hard drive will now be erased and re-formatted. This may take several minutes to several hours. Once the process is complete, follow the on-screen instructions to complete the process and set up your Mac as new.

steps.title: Click the magnifying glass icon.
steps.content: Click the magnifying glass icon. It’s at the top-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Type disk utility.
steps.content: Type disk utility . A list of results will appear.

steps.title: Click Disk Utility – Utilities.
steps.content: Click Disk Utility – Utilities .

steps.title: Click the drive you want to format.
steps.content: Click the drive you want to format. This cannot be the drive on which macOS is installed.

steps.title: Click Erase.
steps.content: Click Erase . It’s at the top of the window.

steps.title: Type a new name for the hard drive.
steps.content: Type a new name for the hard drive.

steps.title: Select the format and scheme.
steps.content: Select the format and scheme. The options you select will vary depending on your needs.

steps.title: Click Erase.
steps.content: Click Erase . The selected hard drive will now be erased and reformatted.
